The monograph, "Comparative
Judicial Criminal Statistics: Six
States, 1931", for which Elva L.
Maquard gave Dr. Marshall statistical assistance, is a part of a larger
study which is concerned with the
formulation of a competent system
of judicial criminal statistics, according to the editorial foreword.
The system is to be used in the
State of Ohio, but it is expected, it
was indicated, to be of service to
other states as well. Accordingly,
the study has extended into New
Jersey, Iowa, Maryland, Rhode Island, and Delaware. The monograph, the foreword says, "was
undertaken partly to throw light
upon the classifications being developed for use in judicial criminal
statistics, and partly as an exploration in the field of comparative judicial criminal statistics.

Data collected is set forth in eight
tables. Table I is a summary presentation of the 15,397 defendants
against whom criminal actions were
filed in the common pleas courts of
Ohio in 1931. For the defendants
in each offense class, the table gives
the procedural outcome in court and
the sentence of treatment assigned
to the defendants found guilty.
Table II presents corresponding
data for 12,502 defendants from
the courts of general criminal jurisdiction in New Jersey. A record
of 9,342 defendants in cases filed
in the Iowa courts of general jurisdiction last .year is shown in Table
III. Maryland's 5,677 cases is recorded in Table IV. Tables V-A
and V-B carry the data for 1,393
defendants in the Superior Courts
of Rhode Island. Table VI accounts for 954 defendants in the
Delaware Courts of general criminal jurisdiction. Table VII indicates the ranking of the individual
offense classes in the various states
and the absolute number of defendants in each class. The last table
given eliminates all cases pending
at the end of the year and also the
"no indictments".

America, was received with a great
deal of praise and enthusiasm. His
paper was especially adapted to the
developments and improvements of
the Pennsylvania Water and Power
Co. A paper by W. P. Taylor, of
the Hopkins, on "Location of Cable
Faults", first won the District Prize
and then the National Prize of the
Institution as being the most valuable and instructive work of the
session.
Group Entertained

Aside from the technical business
at hand, there was much diversion
for the guests. There was a sightseeing trip to Annapolis and a tea,
under the chairmanship of Mrs.
John B. Whitehead, at Carvel
House, for the ladies of the party.
Over a hundred guests attended an
informal dinner dance on Wednesday evening at the Lord Baltimore

The success of this instructive
and pleasant meeting is due almost
entirely to the untiring efforts of
Dr. Kouwenhoven and the chairmen who assisted him.

A Pioneer Work

A pioneer work in state reporting
of criminal statistics, the monograph "Ohio Criminal Statistics,
1931", is believed to be the first
publication of the criminal statistics of an American state within a
single report.
This report does not purport to
be a "model" state report, but is an
attempt to test the feasibility of a
comprehensive report on criminal
statistics in the State of Ohio.

foray—one that brought back from
the courts of general criminal jurisdiction of six states a record of happenings to some 45,265 defendants,
whose cases were filed in 1931. The
states, in the. order of the number of

Jersey, Iowa, Maryland, Rhode Island and Delaware. The data were

Officers After Assembly

The Sophomore Class nominated
seventeen men for its five available'
offices after assembly yesterday.
There ara four candidates for the
offices of president, and secretary,

positions.

"President Hoover looks to the
college students of today to be the
Messiahs of our political future,"
says Frances Lee in an exclusive interview with the President in
Washington, in the November isstie
of College Humor. "The ironbound traditions of the old-time
philosophy are antiquated and old
fogey-ish for our present industrial
generation, and college students are
the logical ones to carry a new banner into national affairs. Science

our present economic and social
life.

tables. Table I is a summary presentation of the 15,397 defendants
against whom criminal actions were

the procedural outcome in court and
the sentence of treatment assigned
to the defendants found guilty.
Table II presents corresponding
data for 12,502 defendants from

of 9,342 defendants in cases filed
in the Iowa courts of general jurisdiction last .year is shown in Table

of Rhode Island. Table VI accounts for 954 defendants in the

A Pioneer Work

A pioneer work in state reporting
of criminal statistics, the monograph "Ohio Criminal Statistics,
1931", is believed to be the first
publication of the criminal statistics of an American state within a
single report.
This report does not purport to
be a "model" state report, but is an
attempt to test the feasibility of a
comprehensive report on criminal
statistics in the State of Ohio.

college students of today to be the
Messiahs of our political future,"
says Frances Lee in an exclusive interview with the President in
Washington, in the November isstie
of College Humor. "The ironbound traditions of the old-time
philosophy are antiquated and old
fogey-ish for our present industrial
generation, and college students are
the logical ones to carry a new banner into national affairs. Science
has become the motivation force in
our present economic and social
life.

made by birth or money. They
